A solution is to set a MAX_NEGATIVE_FITNESS value and always 
translate wit=
h it. It doesn't matter that the new fitnesses will be 
always above 0.0. T=
hey can be compared. 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Johnson" <thoma=
s.j.johnson@...> 
wrote:
>
> The problem I have with this approach is that =
it makes it unclear 
whether
> the population is making progress. Did your =
population hit a new 
fitness
> high this generation because it was better =
than the last 
generation, or
> because last generation's worst fitness was=
 -5 and this 
generation's worst
> fitness is -10?
> If your top-fitness ge=
nome stays the same, and your worst-fitness 
genome
> becomes more negative=
, it appears as though you're making progress 
because
> you're adding more=
 of a correction onto your top performers. 
Certainly you
> can report raw =
fitness instead of adjusted fitness, but keeping 
track of
> both adds some=
 additional complexity that's probably unnecessary.
> 
> Additionally, depe=
nding on how you select the parents for your new
> population, this method =
can also distort selection probabilities by 
reducing
> the fitness spread =
among your top individuals. For instance, if 
your top
> individuals have f=
itnesses of 0.25 and 0.5, it seems that one is 2x 
as good
> as the other. =
But if you have to add 5.0 to correct for an 
individual with a
> negative =
fitness, you get 5.5/5.25=3Dabout a 5% difference. If you're 
using a
> sel=
ection algorithm like roulette wheel or something similar, 
that's going
> =
to make a big difference in how you're selecting parents.
> 
> Thomas
> 
> =

>=
 > > > > Peter is right that you need higher fitness values to mean
> > bet=
ter
> > > > in
> > > > > NEAT. The reason is that fitness sharing equations=
 are 
based on
> > > > the
> > > > > assumption that higher is better. With=
out that, fitness 
sharing
> > > > will
> > > > > malfunction. For the same=
 reason, you should avoid fitness
> > values
> > > > of
> > > > > exactly z=
ero or below.

 the formula, 
although
> > > > that
> > > > > is one option. You can also =
use MAX_FITNESS-
performance+0.001.
